newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian lending rate eases to 8.1 pct.
newsitem.headline: Croatian lending rate eases to 8.1 pct.

text.p: The Croatian lending rate eased to 8.1 percent from 9.3 percent on Wednesday, amid low demand and high supply of kuna funds on Zagreb money market.
Total settlements fell to 51.3 million kuna, against the supply of 203 million kuna.

Dealers said some creditors agreed to Zagrebacka Banka's demands for loans at a reduced annual rate of 7.0 percent, rather than the current 8.0 percent, but most creditors preferred to recall their money.
Call money dropped to 7.0 percent from 9.3 percent and insurance firms' five-10 day loans eased to 8 percent from 8.7 pct. 10-15 day loans fell to 12.5 from Monday's 15 percent.
Overnight trade totalled 72.8 million kuna and left a surplus of 388 million kuna.

The National Bank of Croatia said it stayed out of the foreign exchange market on Wednesday. Its kuna midrates for Thursday were slightly firmer at 5.2556 to the dollar and 3.5410 to the mark. -- Zoran Radosavljevic, Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
